title: Hyperventilation Induced Nystagmus
chief_complaint: I feel off-balance, veering to the right, and never feel straight. I feel lightheaded, 'hung over,' and like I am not in contact with my surroundings.

problem_summary.onset: Acute episode of severe vertigo in June 2010; gradual hearing loss over 10-15 years.
problem_summary.course: Balance improved but never returned to normal; right hearing declined rapidly over 2 years.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss (worse right); Right vestibular schwannoma.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Fullness and constant tinnitus in the right ear; veering to the right.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty walking, used a walker initially; difficulty hearing on the telephone (right ear).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Investigate sudden hearing loss and persistent imbalance.

history.present_illness: Patient noticed increased difficulty hearing in right ear prior to a vertiginous attack in 2010. Prednisone provided no improvement.
history.otologic_history: 10-15 year history of gradual bilateral progressive hearing loss.
history.medical_psych_history: MRI in 2010 reported as 'unremarkable' (later re-reviewed to show small VS).
history.prior_management: Fit with left BICROS hearing aid.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild sloping to moderate rising to mild SNHL in right ear; slight sloping to moderate rising to normal SNHL in left ear.

numeric_results.Configuration: Cookie-bite / U-shaped configuration noted in both ears.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant asymmetry in word recognition scores.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent reflexes in the right ear; present in the left ear.

history.present_illness: Referred to neurotologist in May 2012. MRI re-review identified small vestibular schwannoma in right internal auditory canal.
history.medical_psych_history: Second MRI confirmed tubular mass (VS) 1cm along CN VII-VIII complex.

tests.name: Computerized dynamic posturography (CDP)
tests.key_findings: Generally normal except for center of gravity.

history.otologic_history: Steady decline in pure-tone thresholds noted over previous months.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Severe rising to moderately severe SNHL in right ear (significant decline from V1). Left ear stable.

numeric_results.Right_Thresholds: Low freqs ~80-90 dB HL, rising to ~65 dB HL

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear word recognition dropped to 0%.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Consistent with retrocochlear pathology in the right ear.

numeric_results.Left_Ear: Normal absolute latencies Waves I, III, V
numeric_results.Wave_V_Latency_Shift: Normal on left with increased rate; not tested on right

tests.name: Computerized dynamic posturography (CDP)
tests.key_findings: Decline in performance compared to June. Poor use of vestibular input.

tests.name: Dynamic Subjective Visual Vertical (SVV)
tests.key_findings: Consistent with right unilateral vestibular weakness.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Hyperventilation induced nystagmus beating toward the weaker ear, suggesting an excitatory lesion (irritative focus).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral hereditary sensorineural hearing loss, significantly asymmetric with a rapid decline in the right ear due to a vestibular schwannoma. Right ear thresholds have deteriorated to severe-to-profound levels with 0% word recognition and absent ABR waveforms. Vestibular testing confirms a right unilateral weakness (42% reduced caloric response) and a specific hyperventilation-induced nystagmus beating toward the lesion side, indicating an excitatory/irritative mechanism.
counseling_points: Your MRI and hearing tests confirm a tumor on the hearing and balance nerve on the right side (vestibular schwannoma).
The rapid drop in hearing and clarity in your right ear is due to this tumor affecting the nerve signals.
Your dizziness during stress or heavy breathing is likely caused by the tumor 'irritating' the nerve, sending extra signals to the brain (hyperventilation-induced nystagmus).
Because the tumor is causing active irritation (excitatory signals), we are recommending a treatment (gentamicin) to dampen that nerve's function and stabilize your balance.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated by a long history of 'unexplained' dizziness that was initially dismissed.
Emphasize the feeling of being 'hung over' or disconnected from surroundings.
If asked about breathing or stress, mention that you feel dizzier when you are anxious or panting (e.g., after exercise).
You have significant hearing loss in the right ear; ask the clinician to speak up or speak to your left side.
